text.div:
Media Profile

A photo, video, or audio recording acquired or used in healthcare. The actual content may be inline or provided by direct reference.

Mapping Summary

shr.core.Media maps to Media:
  _Entry.EntryId maps to id
  Language maps to language
  Narrative maps to text
  ImplicitRules maps to implicitRules
  Metadata.VersionId maps to meta.versionId
  Metadata.Profile maps to meta.profile
  Metadata.LastUpdated maps to meta.lastUpdated
  Metadata.SecurityLabel maps to meta.security
  Metadata.Tag maps to meta.tag
  Type maps to type
  Subtype maps to subtype
  Identifier maps to identifier
  MediaSubjectOfRecord maps to subject
  Practitioner maps to operator
  View maps to view
  Device.ManufacturerName maps to deviceName
  PixelHeight maps to height
  PixelWidth maps to width
  Frames maps to frames
  NumberOfSecondsDuration maps to duration
  Attachment maps to content
  RelatedRequest maps to extension
  CareContext maps to extension
  RelevantTime maps to extension
  ReasonCode maps to extension
  Annotation maps to extension
  BodyLocation maps to extension

name: Media
description: A photo, video, or audio recording acquired or used in healthcare. The actual content may be inline or provided by direct reference.

element.name: Media
element.definition: A photo, video, or audio recording acquired or used in healthcare. The actual content may be inline or provided by direct reference.

constraint.human: Height can only be used for a photo or video
Width can only be used for a photo or video
Duration can only be used for an audio or a video
Frames can only be used for a photo

element.name: Media.id
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.name: Media.meta
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.name: Media.implicitRules
element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.name: Media.language
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.name: Media.text
element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.name: Media.contained
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.name: Media.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: relatedrequest
element.definition: The proposal, order, or plan that is partly or wholly fulfilled by the performance of this act.

element.name: Media.extension-relatedrequest.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.name: Media.extension-relatedrequest.extension-extension
element.definition: An Extension

element.name: Media.extension-relatedrequest.url
element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.

element.name: Media.extension-relatedrequest.valueReference
element.definition: A request for a procedure to be performed. May be a proposal or an order.

element.name: carecontext
element.definition: The encounter or episode of care

element.name: relevanttime
element.definition:
The time or time period that the statement addresses.
The clinically relevant time is not necessarily when the information is gathered or when a test is carried out, but for example, when a specimen was collected, or the time period referred to by the question. Use a TimePeriod for a measurement or specimen collection continued over a significant period of time (e.g. 24 hour Urine Sodium).

element.name: reasoncode
element.definition:
The justification, as a code.
Reason is a string or CodeableConcept in DSTU2 but in later versions only a CodeableConcept, so we are not going to support a string.

element.name: Media.extension-reasoncode.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.name: Media.extension-reasoncode.extension-extension
element.definition: An Extension

element.name: Media.extension-reasoncode.url
element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.

element.name: Media.extension-reasoncode.valueCodeableConcept
element.definition: Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list).

element.name: annotation
element.definition: An added or follow-up note, often after the fact, that contains metadata about who made the statement and when.

element.name: bodylocation
element.definition:
A location or structure in the body, including tissues, regions, cavities, and spaces; for example, right elbow, or left ventricle of the heart. Body location is a flexible structure that allows the location to be determined by a single code, or a code plus laterality and/or orientation. The body location can also be specified in relation to one or more body landmarks. SNOMED CT is used in all cases.
+ Code only: The code should include (precoordinate) laterality and/orientation to the degree necessary to completely specify the body location.
+ Code plus laterality and/or orientation: The basic code augmented by codes specifying the body side and/or anatomical orientation.
+ Relation to landmark: The location relative to a landmark is specified by:
- Establishing the location and type of landmark using a body site code and optional laterality/orientation, and
- Specifying the direction and distance from the landmark to the body location.
Note that BodyLocation is a data type, a reusable structure, not a stand-alone entity. The concept is similar to how a postal address can apply to a person, location, or organization. This contrasts with FHIR's stand-alone BodySite (aka BodyStructure in r4) which 'is not ... intended for describing the type of anatomical location but rather a specific body site on a specific patient' (FHIR 3.5).

element.name: status
element.definition: A state that relates to the workflow or interpretation of this resource. Certain status values can modify the meaning of the resource, for example, entered-in-error. When a boolean value is used, Status of true indicates the record is active, false means inactive.

element.name: partof
element.definition: The larger entity that the asserted item is a portion of. For example, an organization part of a larger organization, or an encounter with a hospitalist might be part of a larger hospitalization encounter.

element.name: Media.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Media.type
element.definition: Whether the media is a photo (still image), an audio recording, or a video recording.

binding.description: Whether the Media is a photo, video, or audio

element.name: Media.subtype
element.definition: Details of the type of the media - usually, how it was acquired (what type of device). If images sourced from a DICOM system, are wrapped in a Media resource, then this is the modality.

binding.description: Detailed information about the type of the image - its kind, purpose, or the kind of equipment used to generate it

element.name: Media.identifier
element.definition: Identifiers associated with the image - these may include identifiers for the image itself, identifiers for the context of its collection (e.g. series ids) and context ids such as accession numbers or other workflow identifiers.
element.comments: The identifier label and use can be used to determine what kind of identifier it is.

element.name: Media.subject
element.short: Who/What this Media is a record of
element.definition: Who/What this Media is a record of.

element.name: Media.operator
element.short: The person who generated the image
element.definition: The person who administered the collection of the image.

element.name: Media.view
element.short: Imaging view, e.g. Lateral or Antero-posterior
element.definition: The name of the imaging view e.g. Lateral or Antero-posterior (AP).

binding.description: Imaging view (projection) used when collecting an image

element.name: Media.deviceName
element.definition: The name of the device / manufacturer of the device  that was used to make the recording.

element.name: Media.height
element.short: Height of the image in pixels (photo/video)
element.definition: Height of the image in pixels (photo/video).

element.name: Media.width
element.short: Width of the image in pixels (photo/video)
element.definition: Width of the image in pixels (photo/video).

element.name: Media.frames
element.definition: The number of frames in a photo. This is used with a multi-page fax, or an imaging acquisition context that takes multiple slices in a single image, or an animated gif. If there is more than one frame, this SHALL have a value in order to alert interface software that a multi-frame capable rendering widget is required.

element.name: Media.duration
element.definition: The duration of the recording in seconds - for audio and video.

element.name: Media.content
element.definition: The actual content of the media - inline or by direct reference to the media source file.
element.comments: Recommended content types: image/jpeg, image/png, image/tiff, video/mpeg, audio/mp4, application/dicom. Application/dicom can contain the transfer syntax as a parameter.  For an media that covers a period of time (video/sound), the content.creationTime is the end time. Creation time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching.

element.name: Media
element.definition: A photo, video, or audio recording acquired or used in healthcare. The actual content may be inline or provided by direct reference.

element.name: relatedrequest
element.definition: The proposal, order, or plan that is partly or wholly fulfilled by the performance of this act.

element.name: Media.extension-relatedrequest.valueReference
element.definition: A request for a procedure to be performed. May be a proposal or an order.

element.name: carecontext
element.definition: The encounter or episode of care

element.name: relevanttime
element.definition:
The time or time period that the statement addresses.
The clinically relevant time is not necessarily when the information is gathered or when a test is carried out, but for example, when a specimen was collected, or the time period referred to by the question.
